Summary:
The patient is a 62-year-old female with an admission for pneumonia that developed into Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS). She has been diagnosed with Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) pneumonia. The patient has been experiencing hypoxemic respiratory failure, requiring mechanical ventilation. She also has a deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the left internal jugular vein extending into the subclavian vein. The patient's PTT is elevated, but no anticoagulation therapy has been started yet. She is also showing signs of acute kidney injury (AKI), likely multifactorial, with possible causes including acute tubular necrosis (ATN), contrast-induced nephropathy (CIN), and postrenal causes. The patient has received packed red blood cells (pRBCs) due to anemia, which improved her hemoglobin level. Her leukocyte count is slightly elevated, and she has been on prophylactic medications for DVT, stress ulcers, and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). The patient's blood pressure has been fluctuating, with recent hypertension. She has multiple lines in place, including an arterial line, peripheral IV lines, and a midline PICC line.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): Due to the prolonged duration of mechanical ventilation, the patient is at risk for developing VAP.

   Assessment and Plan
   62F with admission for pneumonia developing into ARDS. Sputum and BAL
   showing MRSA at this point.
   # Hypoxemic respiratory failure:
   ARDS in the setting of MRSA pneumonia. Possibility of other
   complicating factors; however, ANCA negative, [**Doctor First Name **] positive with titer
   only 1:80, HIV status unknown. Has been on a steroid taper. Has had a
   high sedation requirement due to vent dyssynchrony when sedation
   lightened. To address sedation difficulty and attempt to liberate from
   fentanyl and midaz drips we initiated methadone and diazepam IV;
   however, she is still requiring the fentanyl and versed drips though at
   reduced doses. Surveillance sputum culture from [**2191-4-8**] with rare MRSA
   growth.  Worsening peaks pressures this AM
   - Due to high peak pressures this AM, will attempt added bolus sedation
   if PIP>50 for prolonged periods.  Consider paralytic if unable to
   control PIP.
   - Continue Vancomycin for MRSA (dosed on daily random vanc level)
   - Continue solumedrol taper
   - Will attempt to keep euvolemic for now, and anticipate diuresis again
   when kidneys show greater recovery
   - Continue fentanyl patch at 200mcg/hr
   - Continue methadone and diazepam titrated up as needed to allow
   liberation from fentanyl and midaz drips
   - Cont to follow oxygen sats and conservative ABG to guide ventilator
   settings, nebs PRN
   - Distant plan is for trach in the future following further vent
   liberation and diuresis
   # DVT:
   Found to have L-IJ clot extending into subclavian. The line was removed
   however, the patient
s PTT is 74.1 today on heparin SC and so a drip
   was not started. Unclear if this rise in PTT is due only to heparin SC,
   however patient had previously normal PTT on this admission so unlikely
   to have suddenly developed a deficiency in a clotting factor unless
   poor nutritional status is now contributing. Regardless as it is
   currently unknown if PTT represents anticoagulation vs. hypercoaguable
   state.
   - f/u lupus anti-coagulant and anti-phospholipid antibodies studies
   - Cont to follow coags
   - Cont sq heparin for now,  d/c if PTT supratherapeutic.
   - Plan to anticoagulate as needed for DVT pending antibody studies
   # [**Last Name (un) **]:
   Likely multifactorial, differential for her ARF includes ATN (supported
   by appearance of muddy brown casts on sediment examination), CIN from
   recent dye exposure (however her Cr increased more quickly than
   expected after the contrast exposure), postrenal causes unlikely
   following renal U/S on [**2191-4-6**] without note of hydronephrosis or a
   combination of the above. Urine smear for eos was negative, however
   this has low sensitiviy and specificity for AIN. Creatinine decreasing
   to 3.4->3 today.  Has had increasing UOP in the last 24 hours.
   - Renal consult following for renal failure and acidosis, though report
   no indication for dialysis at this time
   - Improved Cr today, will plan to initiate diuresis once Cr<3.
   - Continue following Ca-Phos product for rise above 60
   #Anemia:
   HCT of 22.2 on [**2191-4-9**] after steady downtrend during ICU course.
   Thought to be secondary to phlebotomy. Iron studies performed on
   [**2191-4-9**] and ferritin of 346 along with iron sat of 25% not consistent
   with iron deficiency anemia. Received 2 units pRBC
s with good response
   and is now stable with HCT of 28 this AM. Per report, patient has
   history of pernicious anemia.
   - Continue to trend
   - Check B12 levels
   # Leukocytosis:
   Leukocytosis likely multifactorial with PNA and steroids as
   contributors, WBC count of 11.8 today is slightly up from 9.7
   yesterday; however, no fever spikes consistent with new infection.
   - Continue to trend
   # Hypotension/Hypertension:
   Balance has now swung that patient has recently been hypertensive. This
   likely either unmasked essential hypertension vs. incomplete sedation.
   Will allow some permissive hypertension in setting of [**Last Name (un) **] in order to
   allow adequate perfusion of kidneys given unknown relative normal [**Name2 (NI) 1056**]
   pressure exposure for kidneys.
   - Continue to monitor
   # Access:
   Currently has only A-line and two peripheral IVs. Since pt with
   unstable PIP, will leave PICC line in midline position instead of trip
   to IR today.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: Nutren Renal (Full) - [**2191-4-7**] 08:46 PM 25 mL/hour with

   care and future need for trach and PEG.

Summary:
The patient is a 62-year-old female with a history of pneumonia developing into ARDS. She has been intubated and sedated due to ventilator dyssynchrony. The patient's sputum and BAL show MRSA, and she has been on Vancomycin therapy. She also has a history of DVT and has been found to have a clot in the left Iliac-Jugular vein extending into the subclavian vein. The line was removed, and she is currently on heparin subcutaneously.

The patient's renal function has been declining, with an increasing creatinine level and oliguria. She has been diagnosed with ARF, and the cause is likely multifactorial including ATN, CIN, and postrenal causes. Urine eosinophils were negative, indicating a low likelihood of AIN. Her creatinine level has improved, and she will be started on diuretics once her creatinine level falls below 3.

The patient also has anemia with a HCT of 22.2 on [**2191-4-9**], which is thought to be secondary to phlebotomy. She received 2 units of packed red blood cells with a good response and is now stable with a HCT of 28. She has a history of pernicious anemia, and her B12 levels should be checked.

The patient's leukocytosis is likely multifactorial, and

   Assessment and Plan
   62F with admission for pneumonia developing into ARDS. Sputum and BAL
   showing MRSA at this point.
   # Hypoxemic respiratory failure:
   ARDS in the setting of MRSA pneumonia. Possibility of other
   complicating factors; however, ANCA negative, [**Doctor First Name **] positive with titer
   only 1:80, HIV status unknown. Has been on a steroid taper. Has had a
   high sedation requirement due to vent dyssynchrony when sedation
   lightened. To address sedation difficulty and attempt to liberate from
   fentanyl and midaz drips we initiated methadone and diazepam IV;
   however, she is still requiring the fentanyl and versed drips though at
   reduced doses. Surveillance sputum culture from [**2191-4-8**] with rare MRSA
   growth.  Worsening peaks pressures this AM
   - Continue Vancomycin for MRSA, as Vanco level was 17.2 this AM, likely
   one additional dose of vancomycin today will complete her antibiotic
   course
   - Yesterday was last day of solumedrol
   - Will check PM lytes and begin diuresis with 10 mg IV furosemide if
   creatinine stable or continuing to improve
   - Continue fentanyl patch at 200mcg/hr
   - Continue methadone and diazepam titrated up as needed to allow
   liberation from fentanyl and midaz drips
   - Cont to follow oxygen sats and conservative ABG to guide ventilator
   settings, nebs PRN
   - Contact IP today to let them know that trach and PEG are within
   immediate future for this patient
   # DVT:
   Found to have L-IJ clot extending into subclavian. The line was removed
   however, the patient
s PTT was elevated initially without systemic
   anticoagulation.  Unclear if this rise in PTT is due only to heparin
   SC, however patient had previously normal PTT on this admission so
   unlikely to have suddenly developed a deficiency in a clotting factor
   unless poor nutritional status is now contributing. Currently unknown
   if PTT represents anticoagulation vs. hypercoaguable state. PTT today
   was 65.9.
   - F/U lupus anti-coagulant and anti-phospholipid antibodies studies
   - Cont to follow coags
   - Cont sq heparin for now, d/c if PTT supratherapeutic, start heparin
   drip at low rate today if PTT drops below 50 on evening PTT check
   # [**Last Name (un) **]:
   Likely multifactorial, differential for her [**Last Name (un) **] includes ATN (supported
   by appearance of muddy brown casts on sediment examination), CIN from
   recent dye exposure (however her Cr increased more quickly than
   expected after the contrast exposure), postrenal causes unlikely
   following renal U/S on [**2191-4-6**] without note of hydronephrosis or a
   combination of the above. Urine smear for eos was negative, however
   this has low sensitivity and specificity for AIN. Creatinine decreasing
   to 2.7 today.  Has had increasing UOP in the last 24 hours and
   auto-diuresed to negative fluid balance yesterday. Will  check PM lytes
   and I/O balance.
   - Renal consult following
   - Improved Cr today, will plan to initiate diuresis if creatinine on PM
   lytes check is stable or improved from this AM
   #Anemia:
   HCT of 22.2 on [**2191-4-9**] after steady downtrend during ICU course.
   Thought to be secondary to phlebotomy. Iron studies performed on
   [**2191-4-9**] and ferritin of 346 along with iron sat of 25% not consistent
   with iron deficiency anemia. Received 2 units pRBC
s with good response
   several days ago and is now essentially stable with HCT of 26.4 this
   AM. Per report, patient has history of pernicious anemia. B12 levels
   are WNL as of [**2191-4-11**].
   - Continue to trend
   # Hypotension/Hypertension:
   Balance has now swung that patient has recently been hypertensive. This
   likely either unmasked essential hypertension vs. incomplete sedation.
   Will allow some permissive hypertension in setting of [**Last Name (un) **] in order to
   allow adequate perfusion of kidneys given unknown relative normal [**Name2 (NI) 1056**]
   pressure exposure for kidneys.
   - Continue to monitor
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: Nutren Renal (Full) - [**2191-4-7**] 08:46 PM 25 mL/hour with
   beneprotein added
   Glycemic Control:  Insulin per sliding scale
   Lines:
   PICC on right pulled back to midline and will be advanced in IR today
   to full PICC

   care and future need for trach and PEG.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 62-year-old female with a chief complaint of hypoxemic respiratory failure due to ARDS. She has been admitted for pneumonia and has been on a steroid taper. The patient requires high sedation due to ventilator dyssynchrony. She is still on fentanyl and midazolam drips, although at reduced doses. The patient's sputum and BAL show MRSA, and she has been receiving vancomycin treatment. Her PIP has worsened, and she is being closely monitored. The patient also has a history of DVT with a clot extending into the subclavian vein. Her PTT is elevated, and she is on subcutaneous heparin. Additionally, the patient has renal impairment with an increasing creatinine level, possibly due to ATN, CIN, or postrenal causes. She is being closely monitored, and a renal consult has been requested. The patient's anemia is thought to be secondary to phlebotomy, but her iron studies do not support iron deficiency anemia. She has received 2 units of packed red blood cells (pRBCs) with good response. The patient's blood pressure has recently become hypertensive, and she is being allowed some permissive hypertension. Her nutrition is being provided through enteral feeding.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 59-year-old male with multiple medical complications. The patient has been admitted to the ICU due to acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), pneumonia, renal failure, DVT, hyperglycemia, and anxiety. The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation and has an arterial line in place.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Pneumonia: The patient has been diagnosed with bacterial community-acquired pneumonia (CAP). If left untreated or inadequately treated, pneumonia can lead to worsening lung function, sepsis, and potentially death.

2. Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS): The patient is already diagnosed with ARDS, which is a severe lung condition causing respiratory failure. Complications can include further deterioration of lung function, need for increased ventilatory support, and potential development of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).

3. Renal Failure: The patient is experiencing acute renal failure, as indicated by elevated creatinine and BUN levels. This condition can lead to fluid overload, electrolyte imbalances, and the need for renal replacement therapy such as dialysis.

4. Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT): The patient has a deep vein thrombosis in the upper extremity. If not managed appropriately, it can lead to pulmonary embolism, which is a life-threatening complication.

5. Hyperglycemia: The patient has elevated blood glucose levels, indicating hyperglycemia. Poorly controlled

   - Continue fentanyl patch at 200mcg/hr
   - Continue methadone and diazepam titrated up as needed to allow
   liberation from fentanyl and midaz drips
   - Cont to follow oxygen sats and conservative ABG to guide ventilator
   settings, nebs PRN
   - Distant plan is for trach in the future following further vent
   liberation and diuresis
   # DVT:
   Found to have L-IJ clot extending into subclavian. The line was removed
   however, the patient
s PTT is 74.1 today on heparin SC and so a drip
   was not started. Unclear if this rise in PTT is due only to heparin SC,
   however patient had previously normal PTT on this admission so unlikely
   to have suddenly developed a deficiency in a clotting factor unless
   poor nutritional status is now contributing. Regardless as it is
   currently unknown if PTT represents anticoagulation vs. hypercoaguable
   state.
   - f/u lupus anti-coagulant and anti-phospholipid antibodies studies
   - Cont to follow coags
   - Cont sq heparin for now,  d/c if PTT supratherapeutic.
   - Plan to anticoagulate as needed for DVT pending antibody studies
   # [**Last Name (un) **]:
   Likely multifactorial, differential for her ARF includes ATN (supported
   by appearance of muddy brown casts on sediment examination), CIN from
   recent dye exposure (however her Cr increased more quickly than
   expected after the contrast exposure), postrenal causes unlikely
   following renal U/S on [**2191-4-6**] without note of hydronephrosis or a
   combination of the above. Urine smear for eos was negative, however
   this has low sensitiviy and specificity for AIN. Creatinine decreasing
   to 3.4->3 today.  Has had increasing UOP in the last 24 hours.
   - Renal consult following for renal failure and acidosis, though report
   no indication for dialysis at this time
   - Improved Cr today, will plan to initiate diuresis once Cr<3.
   - Continue following Ca-Phos product for rise above 60
   #Anemia:
   HCT of 22.2 on [**2191-4-9**] after steady downtrend during ICU course.
   Thought to be secondary to phlebotomy. Iron studies performed on
   [**2191-4-9**] and ferritin of 346 along with iron sat of 25% not consistent
   with iron deficiency anemia. Received 2 units pRBC
s with good response
   and is now stable with HCT of 28 this AM. Per report, patient has
   history of pernicious anemia.
   - Continue to trend
   - Check B12 levels
   # Leukocytosis:
   Leukocytosis likely multifactorial with PNA and steroids as
   contributors, WBC count of 11.8 today is slightly up from 9.7
   yesterday; however, no fever spikes consistent with new infection.
   - Continue to trend
   # Hypotension/Hypertension:
   Balance has now swung that patient has recently been hypertensive. This
   likely either unmasked essential hypertension vs. incomplete sedation.
   Will allow some permissive hypertension in setting of [**Last Name (un) **] in order to
   allow adequate perfusion of kidneys given unknown relative normal [**Name2 (NI) 1056**]
   pressure exposure for kidneys.
   - Continue to monitor
   # Access:
   Currently has only A-line and two peripheral IVs. Since pt with
   unstable PIP, will leave PICC line in midline position instead of trip
   to IR today.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: Nutren Renal (Full) - [**2191-4-7**] 08:46 PM 25 mL/hour with
   beneprotein added
   Glycemic Control:  Insulin per sliding scale
   Lines:
   Two right hand peripheral IV
   Arterial Line - [**2191-4-2**] 07:52 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:  Heparin subcutaneous
   Stress ulcer:  PPI IV
   VAP:
   Communication:  Sister/Mother.  [**Name (NI) **] need to discuss overall goals of
   care and future need for trach and PEG.
   Code status: FULL CODE
   Disposition: ICU for now
Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 62-year-old female admitted to the ICU for pneumonia that has progressed to Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS). She has been diagnosed with Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) pneumonia. The patient's condition is complicated by hypoxemic respiratory failure, a deep vein thrombosis (DVT), acute kidney injury (AKI), anemia, leukocytosis, and hypertension/hypertension.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypoxemic Respiratory Failure: The patient's ARDS is worsening, leading to increased peak inspiratory pressures (PIP). This may result in further lung damage and difficulty weaning off mechanical ventilation.
2. DVT: The patient has a confirmed left iliac vein clot extending into the subclavian vein. If not appropriately managed, this could lead to pulmonary embolism.
3. AKI: The patient's creatinine levels are elevated, indicating impaired kidney function. Failure to improve renal function may require dialysis and impact fluid balance management.
4. Anemia: The patient's hematocrit (HCT) levels are low, indicating anemia. Further evaluation of the cause is necessary, including checking B12 levels and considering blood transfusion if needed.
5. Leukocytosis: The patient's white blood cell count is elevated, which can be a response to infection or steroid treatment. Monitoring for signs of infection is crucial.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 59-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), acute renal failure, deep vein thrombosis (DVT), hyperglycemia, and pneumonia. The patient has been intubated and is on mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 250 mL, respiratory rate of 36 breaths per minute, and PEEP at 10 cmH2O. The patient's blood pressure is stable with a reading of 144/60 mmHg, heart rate is 85 beats per minute, and oxygen saturation is 93% on 60% FiO2. The patient has been receiving various medications including fentanyl, midazolam, heparin, lasix, and vancomycin.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): Given the duration of mechanical ventilation, the patient is at risk for developing VAP. Close monitoring of respiratory status and sputum culture is necessary.
2. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) progression to pulmonary embolism (PE): The patient already has a confirmed DVT in the upper extremity. Regular assessment of lower extremities for signs of DVT and consideration of prophylactic anticoagulation therapy are essential.
3. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient's elevated creatinine levels indicate renal dysfunction. Monitoring kidney function and adjusting fluid and medication management accordingly are crucial

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 62-year-old female with a history of pneumonia that has progressed to acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). She has been admitted to the ICU and is currently on mechanical ventilation. The patient has tested positive for methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) in her sputum and BAL cultures. She has been receiving vancomycin therapy but still has persistent MRSA growth. 

The patient's kidney function is being closely monitored, as indicated by frequent checks on her serum creatinine levels. She has been on diuretics to manage fluid balance. 

She also has an elevated PTT, which could be due to heparin therapy or a coagulopathy. Further testing is planned to determine the cause of the elevated PTT. 

The patient's sedation requirement is high, and she is still requiring fentanyl and midazolam infusions despite attempts to wean her off them. 

There is a concern for constipation due to massive doses of systemic opiates. 

The patient's anemia is thought to be secondary to phlebotomy, but further investigation is needed to determine the underlying cause. 

The patient's blood pressure has been fluctuating, and some permissive hypertension is being allowed in order to ensure adequate kidney perfusion. 

The patient's nutritional support is being provided through enteral nutrition. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypoxemic respiratory failure: The patient's ARDS

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 62-year-old female with a history of pneumonia progressing to ARDS. She has been intubated and on mechanical ventilation. The patient's recent events include a consultation for tracheostomy and percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG), improvement in creatinine levels, initiation of diuresis with Lasix, pending tests for lupus/anti-phospholipid antibodies, and a prolonged PTT. The patient's medical conditions include hypoxemic respiratory failure, DVT, renal failure, anemia, and hypertension/hypertension. The patient is currently receiving various medications, including Vancomycin, heparin, fentanyl, midazolam, pantoprazole, and methadone. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.9°C, heart rate of 85 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 144/60 to 170/97 mmHg, respiratory rate of 36 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 93%. The patient's laboratory results show elevated levels of white blood cell count, hemoglobin, platelet count, creatinine, and lactate dehydrogenase, while showing decreased levels of potassium and bicarbonate. The patient's urine output has improved, and her sedation requirements are being managed with methadone and diazepam. The patient is expected to undergo tracheostomy and PEG placement in the near future.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypoxemic respiratory failure: The patient's ARDS has resulted in severe hypoxemia, requiring mechanical ventilation. Continued monitoring and optimization of oxygenation parameters will be necessary.
2. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): The patient has been diagnosed with a left iliac vein clot extending into the subclavian vein. She is currently on subcutaneous heparin, and further evaluation for thrombophilia is planned.
3. Renal failure: The patient has an elevated creatinine level, suggesting renal dysfunction. The cause may be multifactorial, including acute tubular necrosis (ATN), contrast-induced nephropathy (CIN), or postrenal causes. Renal consult is planned to further investigate and manage the renal failure.
4. Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin level is low, indicating anemia. This may be due to phlebotomy or other causes. Iron studies have ruled out iron deficiency anemia. The patient has received packed red blood cells (pRBCs) with a good response.
5. Hypotension/Hypertension: The patient's blood pressure has been fluctuating, with recent episodes of hypertension. This may be due to unmasked essential hypertension or incomplete sedation. Some permissive hypertension may be allowed to ensure adequate renal perfusion.
6. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is low, which may be due to sepsis or other causes. Monitoring of platelet levels and coagulation parameters is important.
7. Infection: The patient has been diagnosed with MRSA pneumonia. Antibiotic therapy with Vancomycin is ongoing. Surveillance cultures will be performed to guide further management.
8. Stress ulcer prophylaxis: The patient is receiving pantoprazole to prevent stress ulcers. Monitoring for signs of gastrointestinal bleeding is necessary.
9. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient is at risk for VAP due to prolonged mechanical ventilation. Measures such as deep vein thrombosis prophylaxis, stress ulcer prophylaxis, and weaning trials will be important in reducing the risk.

Please note that this summary is based on the provided information, and further evaluation by a healthcare professional is recommended for an accurate assessment and management of the patient's conditions.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 62-year-old female admitted for pneumonia, which progressed to acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). The patient has been on mechanical ventilation due to severe hypoxemia. MRSA was identified in sputum and bronchoalveolar lavage cultures. The patient's sedation requirement has been high due to ventilator dyssynchrony. Methadone and diazepam infusions were initiated to reduce sedation and potentially wean off fentanyl and midazolam drips, but the patient still requires reduced doses of fentanyl and versed.

The patient's peaks pressures have worsened, and she has an elevated PTT without systemic anticoagulation. She has a left iliac vein clot extending into the subclavian vein, and her PICC line was removed. The cause of the elevated PTT is unclear, as it could be due to heparin therapy, a clotting factor deficiency, or a hypercoagulable state. Further evaluation of lupus anticoagulant and anti-phospholipid antibodies is planned.

The patient's renal function has improved, with a decreasing creatinine level. She may be started on diuretics if her creatinine remains stable or improves. Anemia has been managed with packed red blood cell transfusions, and iron studies do not indicate iron deficiency anemia. Hypotension and hypertension have been observed, and permissive hypertension is allowed to ensure adequate kidney

   - Contact IP today to let them know that trach and PEG are within
   immediate future for this patient
   # DVT:
   Found to have L-IJ clot extending into subclavian. The line was removed
   however, the patient
s PTT was elevated initially without systemic
   anticoagulation.  Unclear if this rise in PTT is due only to heparin
   SC, however patient had previously normal PTT on this admission so
   unlikely to have suddenly developed a deficiency in a clotting factor
   unless poor nutritional status is now contributing. Currently unknown
   if PTT represents anticoagulation vs. hypercoaguable state. PTT today
   was 65.9.
   - F/U lupus anti-coagulant and anti-phospholipid antibodies studies
   - Cont to follow coags
   - Cont sq heparin for now, d/c if PTT supratherapeutic, start heparin
   drip at low rate today if PTT drops below 50 on evening PTT check
   # [**Last Name (un) **]:
   Likely multifactorial, differential for her [**Last Name (un) **] includes ATN (supported
   by appearance of muddy brown casts on sediment examination), CIN from
   recent dye exposure (however her Cr increased more quickly than
   expected after the contrast exposure), postrenal causes unlikely
   following renal U/S on [**2191-4-6**] without note of hydronephrosis or a
   combination of the above. Urine smear for eos was negative, however
   this has low sensitivity and specificity for AIN. Creatinine decreasing
   to 2.7 today.  Has had increasing UOP in the last 24 hours and
   auto-diuresed to negative fluid balance yesterday. Will  check PM lytes
   and I/O balance.
   - Renal consult following
   - Improved Cr today, will plan to initiate diuresis if creatinine on PM
   lytes check is stable or improved from this AM
   #Anemia:
   HCT of 22.2 on [**2191-4-9**] after steady downtrend during ICU course.
   Thought to be secondary to phlebotomy. Iron studies performed on
   [**2191-4-9**] and ferritin of 346 along with iron sat of 25% not consistent
   with iron deficiency anemia. Received 2 units pRBC
s with good response
   several days ago and is now essentially stable with HCT of 26.4 this
   AM. Per report, patient has history of pernicious anemia. B12 levels
   are WNL as of [**2191-4-11**].
   - Continue to trend
   # Hypotension/Hypertension:
   Balance has now swung that patient has recently been hypertensive. This
   likely either unmasked essential hypertension vs. incomplete sedation.
   Will allow some permissive hypertension in setting of [**Last Name (un) **] in order to
   allow adequate perfusion of kidneys given unknown relative normal [**Name2 (NI) 1056**]
   pressure exposure for kidneys.
   - Continue to monitor
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: Nutren Renal (Full) - [**2191-4-7**] 08:46 PM 25 mL/hour with
   beneprotein added
   Glycemic Control:  Insulin per sliding scale
   Lines:
   PICC on right pulled back to midline and will be advanced in IR today
   to full PICC
   Arterial Line - [**2191-4-2**] 07:52 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:  Heparin subcutaneous
   Stress ulcer:  PPI IV
   VAP:
   Communication:  Sister/Mother.  [**Name (NI) **] need to discuss overall goals of
   care and future need for trach and PEG.
   Code status: FULL CODE
   Disposition: ICU for now
Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 62-year-old female with an admission for pneumonia that progressed into Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS). She has been diagnosed with MRSA pneumonia and is currently on Vancomycin. The patient has a history of pernicious anemia, but her B12 levels are within normal range. She has shown improvement in her creatinine levels and is now able to produce good urine output after foley repositioning. The patient's PTT is elevated, and further investigation into lupus/anti-phospholipid antibodies is pending. She has developed a deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and has an elevated D-dimer level. The patient's anemia is thought to be secondary to phlebotomy, but her iron studies do not indicate iron deficiency anemia. She received 2 units of packed red blood cells (pRBCs) with a good response. The patient's blood pressure has recently become hypertensive, and some permissive hypertension is being allowed to ensure adequate renal perfusion. The patient is expected to undergo tracheostomy and percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) in the near future. Her code status remains as full code. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypoxemic respiratory failure due to ARDS and MRSA pneumonia.
2. DVT with clot extending into the subclavian vein.
3. Elevated PTT indicating possible hypercoagulable

Summary:
The patient is a 59-year-old male who has been admitted to the ICU with a history of altered mental status, constipation, deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the upper extremity, alteration in nutrition, acute renal failure, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), hyperglycemia, respiratory failure, bacterial community-acquired pneumonia (CAP), and anxiety. The patient is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation. There is no mention of allergies in the provided information.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Prolonged mechanical ventilation: The patient's respiratory failure and ARDS may require prolonged mechanical ventilation, which can lead to complications such as ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), ventilator-induced lung injury, and muscle weakness.
2. Nosocomial infections: Being in the ICU, the patient is at risk of developing nosocomial infections such as catheter-related bloodstream infections (CRBSI), urinary tract infections (UTIs), and VAP.
3. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) progression: The patient already has a confirmed DVT in the upper extremity. If left untreated or not properly managed, it can progress to a pulmonary embolism, which is a life-threatening condition.
4. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient's renal function is compromised, as indicated by elevated serum creatinine levels. If not appropriately managed, AKI can lead to chronic kidney disease or require renal replacement therapy.

   Assessment and Plan
   62F with admission for pneumonia developing into ARDS. Sputum and BAL
   showing MRSA at this point.
   # Hypoxemic respiratory failure:
   ARDS in the setting of MRSA pneumonia. Possibility of other
   complicating factors; however, ANCA negative, [**Doctor First Name **] positive with titer
   only 1:80, HIV status unknown. Has completed steroid taper. Has had a
   high sedation requirement due to vent dyssynchrony when sedation
   lightened. To address sedation difficulty and attempt to liberate from
   fentanyl and midaz drips we initiated methadone and diazepam IV;
   however, she is still requiring the fentanyl and versed drips though at
   reduced doses. Surveillance sputum culture from [**2191-4-8**] and [**2191-4-10**]
   with rare MRSA growth. Last dose of Vancomycin was yesterday. Diuresis
   was started yesterday with stable Cr at 2.6 this AM. IP came to see
   patient [**2191-4-13**] and would like vent setting of PEEP 8 and FiO2 50%
   prior to attempted trach and PEG.
   - Continue furosemide boluses with [**Hospital1 **] lytes to monitor renal function
   with goal net negative of 1.5 L over 24 hours
   - Continue fentanyl patch at 200mcg/hr
   - Continue methadone and diazepam titrated up as needed to allow

- The patient is a 62-year-old female with a history of pneumonia that has progressed to ARDS.
- She has been intubated and sedated due to ventilator dyssynchrony.
- MRSA was identified in the sputum and BAL cultures.
- The patient has completed a steroid taper and is still requiring sedation from fentanyl and midazolam drips.
- Methadone and diazepam IV were initiated to address sedation difficulties, but the patient still requires reduced doses of fentanyl and versed drips.
- Diuresis was started yesterday with stable creatinine at 2.6 this morning.
- The patient has a history of pernicious anemia, but B12 levels are within normal limits as of [**2191-4-11**].
- There is evidence of left Iliad clot extending into the subclavian vein, and the line was removed.
- The patient's PTT was elevated initially without systemic anticoagulation.
- The patient has anemia with a HCT of 22.2 on [**2191-4-9**], which is thought to be secondary to phlebotomy.
- Iron studies performed on [**2191-4-9**] showed a ferritin of 346 and an iron saturation of 25%, not consistent with iron deficiency anemia.
- The patient received 2 units of packed red blood cells (pRBCs) with good response several days ago and is now stable with a HCT of 26.5 this morning.
- The patient has been hypertensive recently, likely either unmasked essential hypertension or incomplete sedation.
- The patient's blood glucose levels have been fluctuating between 111 and 156 mg/dL.
- The patient has not had a bowel movement for several days, likely due to massive doses of systemic opiates.
- The patient's respiratory support includes an endotracheal tube, CMV/ASSIST/AutoFlow ventilator mode, set Vt of 260 mL, RR set at 36, PEEP at 10 cmH2O, FiO2 at 55%, and SpO2 of 96%.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): Given the patient's prolonged intubation and ARDS, there is a risk of developing VAP. Surveillance cultures and conservative ABG will be followed to guide ventilator settings, and nebs will be administered as needed.
2. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): The patient has been found to have a left Iliad clot extending into the subclavian vein. The line was removed, and the patient is currently on subcutaneous heparin. Further evaluation of coagulation factors is needed, including lupus anticoagulant and anti-phospholipid antibody studies.

Summary:
The patient is a 62-year-old female with a history of pneumonia that developed into Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS). She has been admitted to the ICU and is currently intubated and sedated. The patient has shown improvement in her condition, with stable creatinine levels and good response to diuresis. However, she still requires sedation and ventilator support.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypoxemic respiratory failure: The patient's ARDS has caused severe lung damage, leading to hypoxemic respiratory failure. Continuous monitoring and adjustment of ventilator settings are necessary to maintain adequate oxygenation.

2. Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT): The patient was found to have a left internal jugular vein clot extending into the subclavian vein. The central line was removed, but her PTT was elevated initially without systemic anticoagulation. She is currently on subcutaneous heparin for DVT prophylaxis and will be monitored closely.

3. Acute Kidney Injury (AKI): The patient's initial renal function tests indicated acute kidney injury. However, her creatinine levels have been steadily decreasing, suggesting improvement. Close monitoring of renal function and diuresis will continue.

4. Constipation: The patient has not had a bowel movement in several days, likely due to massive doses of systemic opiates. Increasing the bowel regimen and considering a sodium bicarbonate enema will help relieve constipation.

Summary:
The patient is a 62-year-old female with a chief complaint of hypoxemic respiratory failure secondary to ARDS. She has completed a steroid taper and has been on ventilatory support. The patient has MRSA pneumonia and has shown some improvement in oxygen saturation levels. She is still requiring sedation and has ongoing diuresis with stable creatinine levels.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypoxemic Respiratory Failure: The patient's primary concern is her hypoxemic respiratory failure due to ARDS. This condition can lead to inadequate oxygenation of tissues and organs, potentially resulting in multi-organ dysfunction or failure.

2. MRSA Infection: The patient has MRSA pneumonia, which increases the risk of antibiotic resistance and treatment challenges. If not appropriately managed, the infection may worsen or spread to other parts of the body.

3. Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT): The patient has been diagnosed with a left internal jugular vein DVT extending into the subclavian vein. This increases the risk of pulmonary embolism if the clot dislodges and travels to the lungs.

4. Lupus Anticoagulant and Positive Inhibitor Screen: The patient has tested positive for lupus anticoagulant and an inhibitor screen. This finding may complicate anticoagulation therapy and increase the risk of bleeding or clotting disorders.

5. Anemia: The patient has anemia with a HCT of 22.2

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 59-year-old male admitted to the ICU with altered mental status, respiratory distress, and renal failure. The patient has been diuresed with furosemide and has had two large soft bowel movements. Allergies include hives from sulfonamide antibiotics. The patient is currently receiving midazolam and fentanyl infusions, as well as other medications including heparin, pantoprazole, and furosemide.

Vital signs show a temperature of 37.3°C, heart rate of 85 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 174/78 mmHg to 182/100 mmHg, respiratory rate of 15 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 96%. The patient's heart rhythm is sinus rhythm.

Fluid balance shows an intake of 1,257 mL, including 470 mL through PO, 600 mL through TF, and 477 mL through IVF. Output includes 2,990 mL of urine and 1,040 mL of blood products.

The patient is on mechanical ventilation with a set tidal volume of 260 mL, respiratory rate of 36 breaths per minute, PEEP of 10 cmH2O, FiO2 of 55%, and plateau pressure of 43 cmH2O. The patient's ABG results show a pH of 7.36, PaCO2 of 57 mmHg, and PaO2 of 142 mmHg.

Physical examination findings include a right radial pulse not assessed, left radial pulse not assessed, right DP pulse not assessed, and left DP pulse not assessed. Skin, neurologic, and peripheral vascular examinations were also not assessed.

Lab results show elevated white blood cell count of 271 K/uL, hemoglobin of 8.8 g/dL, sodium of 111 mg/dL, potassium of 3.9 mEq/L, chloride of 76 mg/dL, bicarbonate of 30 mEq/L, blood urea nitrogen of 27.7%, creatinine of 2.6 mg/dL, glucose of 156 mg/dL, and platelet count of 278 K/uL.

Assessment and plan include altered mental status, constipation, deep vein thrombosis in the upper extremity, alteration in nutrition, acute renal failure, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), hyperglycemia, respiratory failure, community-acquired pneumonia, anxiety, and ICU care including nutrition, glycemic control, and prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcers, and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Pulmonary complications: Given the presence of ARDS, the patient is at risk for further respiratory deterioration and potential need for extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO).
2. Renal complications: The patient's acute renal failure may progress to chronic renal failure if not properly managed.
3. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): The patient's immobilization and underlying conditions increase the risk for DVT, which can lead to pulmonary embolism if not prophylaxed appropriately.
4. Infection: The patient's immune system may be compromised due to the underlying medical conditions, increasing the risk for hospital-acquired infections, including ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
5. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's constipation and alteration in nutrition may increase the risk for gastrointestinal bleeding or perforation.
6. Cardiac complications: The patient's hypertension and potential cardiac history increase the risk for cardiac events such as myocardial infarction or heart failure exacerbation.
7. Hyperglycemia: The patient's high glucose levels require careful monitoring and management to prevent complications related to hyperglycemia.
8. Pressure ulcers: The patient's immobilization and altered mental status increase the risk for developing pressure ulcers.

   Assessment and Plan
   62F with admission for pneumonia developing into ARDS. Sputum and BAL
   showing MRSA at this point.
   # Hypoxemic respiratory failure:
   ARDS in the setting of MRSA pneumonia. Possibility of other
   complicating factors; however, ANCA negative, [**Doctor First Name **] positive with titer
   only 1:80, HIV status unknown. Has completed steroid taper. Has had a
   high sedation requirement due to vent dyssynchrony when sedation
   lightened. To address sedation difficulty and attempt to liberate from
   fentanyl and midaz drips we initiated methadone and diazepam IV;
   however, she is still requiring the fentanyl and versed drips though at
   reduced doses. Surveillance sputum culture from [**2191-4-8**] and [**2191-4-10**]
   with rare MRSA growth. Last dose of Vancomycin was yesterday. IP came
   to see patient [**2191-4-13**] and would like vent setting of PEEP 8 and FiO2
   50% prior to attempted trach and PEG. Encouraging that drip sedation
   being liberated little by little and FiO2 is down to 55% today. Has
   ongoing diuresis with stable Cr
   - Continue furosemide boluses with [**Hospital1 **] lytes to monitor renal function
   with goal net negative
   - Continue fentanyl patch at 200mcg/hr
   - Continue methadone and diazepam (PO route) titrated up as needed to
   allow liberation from fentanyl and midaz drips
   - Cont to follow oxygen sats and conservative ABG to guide ventilator
   settings, nebs PRN
   - esophageal balloon taken out
   - cont slow PEEP taper
   - PIP/Plateau levels persistently high today, ETT on AM CXR appears to
   abut carina.  Will pull back ETT and redo CXR and then reassess
   respiratory mechanics.
   # DVT:
   Found to have L-IJ clot extending into subclavian. The line was removed
   however, the patient
s PTT was elevated initially without systemic
   anticoagulation.  Unclear if this rise in PTT is due only to heparin
   SC, however patient had previously normal PTT on this admission so
   unlikely to have suddenly developed a deficiency in a clotting factor
   unless poor nutritional status is now contributing. Currently unknown
   if PTT represents anticoagulation vs. hypercoaguable state.
   - F/U ACA antibodies
   - Hematology consult for positive lupus anticoagulant as well as
   positive inhibitor screen in setting of new DVT, likely complicated by
   subcutaneous heparin administration.  Recs avoid hydralazine, would not
   use IV heparin, cannot use lovenox due to renal function
   - Cont to follow coags [**Hospital1 **]
   - Hold heparin subcutaneous today in anticipation of Monday procedures
   # [**Last Name (un) **]:
   Thought to originally be attributed to ATN. Resolving with Cr steadily
   downtrending at 2.5 today in face of diuresis yesterday. No longer
   struggling with hyperphosphatemia.
   - Will check PM lytes and I/O balance.
   - Discontinued calcium acetate
   - patient with slowly increasing hypernatremia, will increase free
   water flushes to 150cc q6.
   # Constipation:
   Patient with two large stools yesterday.
   - Continue lactulose PO and PR as needed
   - If lactulose fails, will consider PO narcan to relief constipation
   #Anemia:
   HCT of 22.2 on [**2191-4-9**] after steady downtrend during ICU course.
   Thought to be secondary to phlebotomy. Iron studies performed on
   [**2191-4-9**] and ferritin of 346 along with iron sat of 25% not consistent
   with iron deficiency anemia. Received 2 units pRBC
s with good response
   several days ago and is now essentially stable with HCT of 26.5 this
   AM. Per report, patient has history of pernicious anemia. B12 levels
   are WNL as of [**2191-4-11**].
   - Continue to trend
   # Hypotension/Hypertension:
   Balance has now swung that patient has recently been hypertensive. This
   likely either unmasked essential hypertension vs. incomplete sedation.
   Will allow some permissive hypertension in setting of [**Last Name (un) **] in order to
   allow adequate perfusion of kidneys given unknown relative normal [**Name2 (NI) 1056**]
   pressure exposure for kidneys.
   - Continue to monitor
   - will increase diltiazem to 60mg qid
   ICU Care

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 62-year-old female with a chief complaint of hypoxemic respiratory failure due to ARDS secondary to MRSA pneumonia. The patient has a history of pneumonia that progressed to ARDS, and she is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation. She has ongoing diuresis with stable creatinine levels and is being monitored for renal function.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypotension/Hypertension: The patient has been hypertensive recently, which may be due to unmasked essential hypertension or incomplete sedation. It is important to monitor blood pressure and allow some permissive hypertension to ensure adequate kidney perfusion.
2. DVT: The patient was found to have a left internal jugular vein (L-IJ) clot extending into the subclavian vein. The line was removed, but the patient's PTT was elevated without systemic anticoagulation. There is uncertainty about whether this rise in PTT is due to heparin or a hypercoagulable state.
3. Anemia: The patient has a history of pernicious anemia, and her HCT has been steadily decreasing during the ICU course. She received 2 units of packed red blood cells (pRBC) with a good response and is now stable with an HCT of 26.5.
4. Constipation: The patient had two large stools yesterday, indicating that her constipation is improving. She will continue to receive lactulose

Based on the provided information, the patient is a 62-year-old female with an admission for pneumonia that has developed into Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS). The patient's sputum and bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) show Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) infection. The patient is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation.

The patient has been diagnosed with Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) with a clot extending into the subclavian vein. The central line was removed, but the patient's partial thromboplastin time (PTT) was elevated initially without systemic anticoagulation. It is unclear if this rise in PTT is due to subcutaneous heparin or a hypercoagulable state. The patient also tested positive for lupus anticoagulant.

The patient's kidney function has improved, and the creatinine level is now 2.5. The patient previously had acute tubular necrosis (ATN), but it is resolving. The patient's anemia is secondary to phlebotomy and possibly pernicious anemia, for which she received packed red blood cells (pRBCs).

The patient's blood pressure has been fluctuating, with recent episodes of hypertension. This could be due to unmasked essential hypertension or incomplete sedation. The goal is to allow some permissive hypertension for adequate renal perfusion.

Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 59-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU with a history of multiple medical conditions including acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), pneumonia, acute renal failure, deep vein thrombosis (DVT), hyperglycemia, and constipation. The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation with an endotracheal tube, receiving supplemental oxygen and assisted ventilation. The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 37.2 degrees Celsius, heart rate of 82 beats per minute, blood pressure of 175/75 mmHg, respiratory rate of 23 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 96%. Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 59-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of altered mental status. The patient has been intubated and placed on mechanical ventilation. He is currently receiving multiple medications including fentanyl, midazolam, pantoprazole, and heparin.

The patient's vital signs show a blood pressure of 164/72 mmHg, heart rate of 72 bpm, respiratory rate of 36 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 95%. His temperature is within normal range at 36.9°C.

The patient's fluid balance shows an intake of 1,735 mL and output of 2,440 mL, resulting in a negative balance of 705 mL. His urine output is 2,340 mL, indicating good renal function.

The patient's laboratory results reveal a white blood cell count of 9.5 K/uL, hemoglobin of 8.2 g/dL, sodium of 130 mg/dL, potassium of 4.0 mEq/L, creatinine of 2.2 mg/dL, and blood glucose of 111 mg/dL. Other lab values are within normal limits.

The patient's arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis shows a pH of 7.41, partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2) of 34 mmHg, oxygen saturation (SaO2) of 95%, and bicarbonate (HCO3-) level of 31 mEq/L. These results indicate normal acid-base balance.

The patient's physical examination reveals no abnormalities in the peripheral vascular system, skin, or neurologic assessment. However, his respiratory support indicates the use of an endotracheal tube with controlled mechanical ventilation (CMV) mode, set tidal volume (Vt) of 260 mL, respiratory rate (RR) of 36 breaths per minute, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 10 cmH2O, and fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 55%.

The patient's assessment and plan include several conditions such as altered mental status, constipation, deep vein thrombosis (DVT), alteration in nutrition, acute renal failure, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), hyperglycemia, respiratory failure, bacterial pneumonia, anxiety, and ICU care.

Potential medical complications that can arise in this patient's case include:

1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): Being intubated for an extended period increases the risk of developing pneumonia.
2. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE): Immobility and hypercoagulability can lead to the formation of blood clots in the deep veins, which can potentially dislodge and travel to the lungs.
3. Nosocomial infections: Prolonged ICU stay increases the risk of acquiring healthcare-associated infections.
4. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient's elevated creatinine levels suggest impaired renal function, which may worsen due to factors such as fluid overload or nephrotoxic medications.
5. Pressure ulcers: Immobility and pressure from the endotracheal tube can increase the risk of developing pressure ulcers.
6. Delirium: The patient's altered mental status may progress to delirium, especially with prolonged sedation and ICU stay.
7. Crit

   Assessment and Plan
   62F with admission for pneumonia developing into ARDS. Sputum and BAL
   showing MRSA at this point.
   # Hypoxemic respiratory failure:
   ARDS in the setting of MRSA pneumonia. Possibility of other
   complicating factors; however, ANCA negative, [**Doctor First Name **] positive with titer
   only 1:80, HIV status unknown. Has completed steroid taper. Has had a
   high sedation requirement due to vent dyssynchrony when sedation
   lightened. To address sedation difficulty and attempt to liberate from
   fentanyl and midaz drips we initiated methadone and diazepam IV;
   however, she is still requiring the fentanyl and versed drips though at
   reduced doses. Surveillance sputum culture from [**2191-4-8**] and [**2191-4-10**]
   with rare MRSA growth. Last dose of Vancomycin was yesterday. IP came
   to see patient [**2191-4-13**] and would like vent setting of PEEP 8 and FiO2
   50% prior to attempted trach and PEG. Encouraging that drip sedation
   being liberated little by little and FiO2 is down to 55% today. Has
   ongoing diuresis with stable Cr
   - will start lasix gtt for increased diuresis
   - will decrease RR with permissive hypercapnea in attempt to decrease
   PIP
   - Continue fentanyl patch at 200mcg/hr
   - Continue methadone and diazepam (PO route) titrated up as needed to
   allow liberation from fentanyl and midaz drips
   - Cont to follow oxygen sats and conservative ABG to guide ventilator
   settings, nebs PRN
   - esophageal balloon taken out
   - cont slow PEEP taper
   # DVT:
   Found to have L-IJ clot extending into subclavian. The line was removed
   however, the patient
s PTT was elevated initially without systemic
   anticoagulation.  Unclear if this rise in PTT is due only to heparin
   SC, however patient had previously normal PTT on this admission so
   unlikely to have suddenly developed a deficiency in a clotting factor
   unless poor nutritional status is now contributing. Currently unknown
   if PTT represents anticoagulation vs. hypercoaguable state.
   - F/U ACA antibodies
   - daily coags
   - Hematology consult for positive lupus anticoagulant as well as
   positive inhibitor screen in setting of new DVT, likely complicated by
   subcutaneous heparin administration.  Recs avoid hydralazine, would not
   use IV heparin, cannot use lovenox due to renal function
   - Cont to follow coags [**Hospital1 **]
   - Hold heparin subcutaneous today in anticipation of Monday procedures
   # [**Last Name (un) **]:
   Thought to originally be attributed to ATN. Resolving with Cr steadily
   downtrending at 2.5 today in face of diuresis yesterday. No longer
   struggling with hyperphosphatemia.  Continues to have increasing
   sodium.
   - Will check PM lytes and I/O balance.
   - Discontinued calcium acetate
   - will change free water flushes to 150cc q4.
   # Constipation:
   Patient with two large stools yesterday.
   - Continue lactulose PO and PR as needed
   - If lactulose fails, will consider PO narcan to relief constipation
   #Anemia:
   HCT of 22.2 on [**2191-4-9**] after steady downtrend during ICU course.
   Thought to be secondary to phlebotomy. Iron studies performed on
   [**2191-4-9**] and ferritin of 346 along with iron sat of 25% not consistent
   with iron deficiency anemia. Received 2 units pRBC
s with good response
   several days ago and is now essentially stable with HCT of 26.5 this
   AM. Per report, patient has history of pernicious anemia. B12 levels
   are WNL as of [**2191-4-11**].
   - Continue to trend
   - plan transfusion if HgB <7
   # Hypotension/Hypertension:
   Balance has now swung that patient has recently been hypertensive. This
   likely either unmasked essential hypertension vs. incomplete sedation.
   Will allow some permissive hypertension in setting of [**Last Name (un) **] in order to
   allow adequate perfusion of kidneys given unknown relative normal [**Name2 (NI) 1056**]
   pressure exposure for kidneys.
   - Continue to monitor
   - cont diltiazem to 60mg qid
   ICU Care

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
- The patient is a 62-year-old female admitted for pneumonia, which developed into Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS).
- She has MRSA pneumonia and is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation.
- The patient has been sedated due to ventilator dyssynchrony but is slowly being weaned off sedation.
- There have been attempts to extubate the patient, but she requires continued ventilatory support.
- The patient has a history of pernicious anemia and received 2 units of packed red blood cells (pRBCs) with a good response.
- She has ongoing diuresis with stable creatinine levels and will start Lasix gtt for increased diuresis.
- The patient has a left internal jugular (L-IJ) clot extending into the subclavian, and the line was removed.
- The patient's PTT was elevated initially without systemic anticoagulation, and it is unclear if this rise in PTT is due to heparin subcutaneous, a hypercoagulable state, or a deficiency in a clotting factor.
- The patient has a positive lupus anticoagulant and inhibitor screen, which complicates the management of her DVT.
- The patient's sodium levels are increasing, and her electrolytes and I/O balance should be monitored.
- The patient is at risk for constipation, and lactulose PO and PR will be continued

   - Continue furosemide boluses with [**Hospital1 **] lytes to monitor renal function
   with goal net negative
   - Continue fentanyl patch at 200mcg/hr
   - Continue methadone and diazepam (PO route) titrated up as needed to
   allow liberation from fentanyl and midaz drips
   - Cont to follow oxygen sats and conservative ABG to guide ventilator
   settings, nebs PRN
   - esophageal balloon taken out
   - cont slow PEEP taper
   # DVT:
   Found to have L-IJ clot extending into subclavian. The line was removed
   however, the patient
s PTT was elevated initially without systemic
   anticoagulation.  Unclear if this rise in PTT is due only to heparin
   SC, however patient had previously normal PTT on this admission so
   unlikely to have suddenly developed a deficiency in a clotting factor
   unless poor nutritional status is now contributing. Currently unknown
   if PTT represents anticoagulation vs. hypercoaguable state.
   - F/U ACA antibodies
   - Hematology consult for positive lupus anticoagulant as well as
   positive inhibitor screen in setting of new DVT, likely complicated by
   subcutaneous heparin administration.  Recs avoid hydralazine, would not
   use IV heparin, cannot use lovenox due to renal function
   - Cont to follow coags [**Hospital1 **]
   - Hold heparin subcutaneous today in anticipation of Monday procedures
   # [**Last Name (un) **]:
   Thought to originally be attributed to ATN. Resolving with Cr steadily
   downtrending at 2.5 today in face of diuresis yesterday. No longer
   struggling with hyperphosphatemia.
   - Will check PM lytes and I/O balance.
   - Discontinued calcium acetate
   - free water flushes to 150cc q6.
   # Constipation:
   Patient with two large stools yesterday.
   - Continue lactulose PO and PR as needed
   - If lactulose fails, will consider PO narcan to relief constipation
   #Anemia:
   HCT of 22.2 on [**2191-4-9**] after steady downtrend during ICU course.
   Thought to be secondary to phlebotomy. Iron studies performed on
   [**2191-4-9**] and ferritin of 346 along with iron sat of 25% not consistent
   with iron deficiency anemia. Received 2 units pRBC
s with good response
   several days ago and is now essentially stable with HCT of 26.5 this
   AM. Per report, patient has history of pernicious anemia. B12 levels
   are WNL as of [**2191-4-11**].
   - Continue to trend
   # Hypotension/Hypertension:
   Balance has now swung that patient has recently been hypertensive. This
   likely either unmasked essential hypertension vs. incomplete sedation.
   Will allow some permissive hypertension in setting of [**Last Name (un) **] in order to
   allow adequate perfusion of kidneys given unknown relative normal [**Name2 (NI) 1056**]
   pressure exposure for kidneys.
   - Continue to monitor
   - cont diltiazem to 60mg qid
   ICU Care

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 62-year-old female with an admission for pneumonia that progressed to acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). The patient's sputum and bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) cultures showed methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) infection. The patient has completed a steroid taper, but still requires high levels of sedation due to ventilator dyssynchrony. The patient's sedation is being managed with methadone and diazepam, but she is still on reduced doses of fentanyl and midazolam infusions. The patient's FiO2 has been decreased to 55% today, and there is ongoing diuresis with stable creatinine levels.

Potential medical complications:
1. Hypoxemic respiratory failure: The patient has ARDS, which can lead to severe hypoxemia and respiratory failure.
2. MRSA infection: The presence of MRSA in the sputum and BAL cultures indicates a bacterial infection that may require appropriate antibiotic therapy.
3. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): The patient was found to have a left iliac vein clot extending into the subclavian vein. This increases the risk of pulmonary embolism.
4. Coagulation issues: The patient has an elevated PTT despite subcutaneous heparin administration. This could indicate the presence of a coagulation inhibitor, such as lupus anticoagulant or heparin-induced thrombocytopenia.
5. Renal function: The patient's renal function is currently stable, but there are concerns about ongoing diuresis and the need for careful monitoring of electrolyte balance and fluid intake/output.
6. Anemia: The patient's HCT has been trending down during the ICU course and was found to be 22.2 on [**2191-4-9**]. The patient received 2 units of packed red blood cells (pRBCs) with a good response, and the HCT is now stable at 26.5.
7. Hypotension/Hypertension: The patient has recently been hypertensive, which may be due to unmasked essential hypertension or incomplete sedation. Some permissive hypertension is being allowed to ensure adequate renal perfusion.

Please note that this summary and potential medical complications are based on the information provided in the progress note.

   Assessment and Plan
   62F with admission for pneumonia developing into ARDS. Sputum and BAL
   showing MRSA at this point.
   # Hypoxemic respiratory failure:
   ARDS in the setting of MRSA pneumonia. Possibility of other
   complicating factors; however, ANCA negative, [**Doctor First Name **] positive with titer
   only 1:80, HIV status unknown. Has completed steroid taper. Has had a
   high sedation requirement due to vent dyssynchrony when sedation
   lightened. To address sedation difficulty and attempt to liberate from
   fentanyl and midaz drips we initiated methadone and diazepam IV;
   however, she is still requiring the fentanyl and versed drips though at
   reduced doses. Surveillance sputum culture from [**2191-4-8**] and [**2191-4-10**]
   with rare MRSA growth. Completed course of Vancomycin. IP came to see
   patient [**2191-4-13**] and would like vent setting of PEEP 8 and FiO2 50%
   prior to attempted trach and PEG. Encouraging that drip sedation being
   liberated little by little and FiO2 is down to 55%. Has ongoing
   diuresis with stable Cr
   - will cont lasix gtt for increased diuresis
   - decreased RR with permissive hypercapnea in attempt to decrease PIP,
   will cont to attempt wean settings
   - Continue fentanyl patch at 200mcg/hr
   - Continue methadone and diazepam (PO route) titrated up as needed to
   allow liberation from fentanyl and midaz drips
   - Cont to follow oxygen sats and conservative ABG to guide ventilator
   settings, nebs PRN
   - esophageal balloon taken out
   - cont slow PEEP taper
   - f/u with IP re:plan for trach and PEG this week,
   # DVT:
   Found to have L-IJ clot extending into subclavian. The line was removed
   however, the patient
s PTT was elevated initially without systemic
   anticoagulation.  Unclear if this rise in PTT is due only to heparin
   SC, however patient had previously normal PTT on this admission so
   unlikely to have suddenly developed a deficiency in a clotting factor
   unless poor nutritional status is now contributing. Currently unknown
   if PTT represents anticoagulation vs. hypercoaguable state. ACA
   antibodies, IgG positive, IgM negative
   - daily coags
   - Hematology consult for positive lupus anticoagulant as well as
   positive inhibitor screen in setting of new DVT, likely complicated by
   subcutaneous heparin administration.  Recs avoid hydralazine, would not
   use IV heparin, cannot use lovenox due to renal function
   - Cont to follow coags [**Hospital1 **]
   - plan to hold heparin subcutaneous today in anticipation of potential
   procedures
   # [**Last Name (un) **]:
   Thought to originally be attributed to ATN. Resolving with Cr steadily
   downtrending at 2.1 today with continued diuresis. No longer struggling
   with hyperphosphatemia.  Continues to have high relatively sodium but
   improved.
   - follow lytes and I/O balance.
   - Discontinued calcium acetate
   - free water flushes at 150cc q4.
   # Constipation:
   - Continue lactulose PO and PR as needed
   - If lactulose fails, could consider PO narcan to relief constipation
   #Anemia:
   HCT of 22.2 on [**2191-4-9**] after steady downtrend during ICU course.
   Thought to be secondary to phlebotomy. Iron studies performed on
   [**2191-4-9**] and ferritin of 346 along with iron sat of 25% not consistent
   with iron deficiency anemia. Received 2 units pRBC
s with good response
   several days ago and is now essentially stable with HCT of 26.5 this
   AM. Per report, patient has history of pernicious anemia. B12 levels
   are WNL as of [**2191-4-11**].
   - Continue to trend
   - plan transfusion if HgB <7
   # Hypotension/Hypertension:
   Balance has now swung that patient has recently been hypertensive. This
   likely either unmasked essential hypertension vs. incomplete sedation.
   Will allow some permissive hypertension in setting of [**Last Name (un) **] in order to
   allow adequate perfusion of kidneys given unknown relative normal [**Name2 (NI) 1056**]
   pressure exposure for kidneys.
   - Continue to monitor
   - cont diltiazem to 60mg qid

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 62-year-old female with a chief complaint of hypoxemic respiratory failure. She was admitted for pneumonia that developed into Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS). The sputum and bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) showed Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) infection. The patient has completed a course of Vancomycin.

The patient has been requiring high levels of sedation due to ventilator dyssynchrony. To address this, methadone and diazepam IV were initiated, but the patient still requires reduced doses of fentanyl and midazolam drips. The patient's oxygen saturation is being closely monitored, and there has been some improvement with FiO2 reduced to 55%.

The patient has ongoing diuresis with stable creatinine levels. Lasix infusion is being continued for increased diuresis, and there is a plan to taper PEEP slowly. The patient's tracheostomy and percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) placement are being planned for this week.

The patient was found to have a left iliac vein thrombus extending into the subclavian vein. The central line was removed, but the patient's Prothrombin Time (PTT) was elevated initially without systemic anticoagulation. The patient has positive lupus anticoagulant antibodies and an inhibitor screen, suggesting a hypercoagulable

Summary:
The patient is a 62-year-old female with a history of pneumonia developing into Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS). She has been admitted to the ICU for respiratory failure and has shown MRSA in her sputum and bronchoalveolar lavage. The patient is intubated and sedated due to ventilator dyssynchrony. Methadone and diazepam have been initiated to attempt to liberate her from the fentanyl and midazolam drips, but she still requires reduced doses of these medications. The patient also has a left internal jugular vein thrombus extending into the subclavian vein, which was removed, and her PTT was elevated initially without systemic anticoagulation. She has been found to have a positive lupus anticoagulant with a titer of 1:80 and a positive inhibitor screen. There is uncertainty regarding the elevated PTT, whether it represents anticoagulation or a hypercoagulable state. The patient's renal function is stable with a creatinine of 2.5, and she is undergoing diuresis with Lasix. She has ongoing diuresis with stable creatinine and will start Lasix gtt for increased diuresis. The patient's sodium levels are increasing, and she has hyperphosphatemia. She has a history of anemia, which is thought to be secondary to phlebotomy, but her ferritin and iron saturation

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 62-year-old female admitted for pneumonia that has progressed into Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS). She is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation. The patient has been diagnosed with Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) pneumonia and has completed a course of Vancomycin. The patient is also suspected to have deep vein thrombosis (DVT), which was found in the left internal jugular vein. She has an elevated PTT and positive lupus anticoagulant, indicating a hypercoagulable state. The patient's kidney function has improved with stable creatinine levels, and she is undergoing diuresis. She also has anemia with a hemoglobin concentration of 22.2, which is being treated with packed red blood cell transfusions. Her blood pressure is being managed with diltiazem, and she is on multiple medications for sedation.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient is at risk of developing VAP due to prolonged mechanical ventilation. Close monitoring of respiratory status and surveillance cultures are recommended.
2. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT)/Pulmonary embolism (PE): The patient has a history of DVT and is at increased risk for developing further thrombotic events. Anticoagulation therapy should be continued, and regular monitoring of coagulation parameters is essential.
3. Acute

Summary:
The patient's condition is complex and involves multiple medical complications. Based on the information provided in the progress note, the potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) - The patient has been diagnosed with a DVT in the upper extremity. This is a serious condition where a blood clot forms in a deep vein, typically in the legs. If the clot dislodges and travels to the lungs, it can cause a pulmonary embolism, which can be life-threatening.

2. Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) - The patient is experiencing acute lung injury and has been diagnosed with ARDS. ARDS is a severe condition that occurs when the lungs become inflamed and filled with fluid, making it difficult to breathe. It can be caused by various factors, including infections, trauma, or inhalation injuries.

3. Renal Failure - The patient's renal function has deteriorated, leading to acute renal failure. This means that the kidneys are not able to adequately filter waste products from the blood, resulting in a buildup of toxins and electrolyte imbalances. Renal failure can be life-threatening if not treated promptly and appropriately.

4. Pneumonia - The patient has been diagnosed with community-acquired pneumonia (CAP). Pneumonia is an infection in the lungs that can cause symptoms such as cough, fever, and difficulty breathing. If left untreated, pneumonia can worsen the patient's respiratory status and lead to

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 62-year-old woman with severe late-stage ARDS (Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome) from nosocomial MRSA pneumonia. She also has acute renal failure (ARF), a right internal jugular vein (RIJ) clot, and possible +lupus anticoagulant. 

The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation with an endotracheal tube, with a set tidal volume (Vt) of 260 mL and a respiratory rate (RR) of 28 breaths per minute. The fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) is set at 55%, and the positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) is at 10 cmH2O. The patient's blood pressure is 110/50 mmHg, heart rate is 87 beats per minute, and oxygen saturation is 95%. 

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 7.8 K/uL, hemoglobin level of 9.0 g/dL, platelet count of 211 K/uL, sodium level of 135 mg/dL, potassium level of 4.6 mEq/L, and glucose level of 121 mg/dL. Other lab values are within normal ranges. 

The patient's arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis reveals a pH of 7.37, partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2) of 34 mmHg, partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2) of 124 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 95%. 

The patient's physical examination findings include crackles in the respiratory chest, warm skin, and no distress. Neurological examination is not assessed due to the patient's inability to follow commands or respond appropriately. 

The potential medical complications that can arise include worsening respiratory failure, coagulopathy, and hot neural neuropathy (HOTN). The patient's ARDS and ventilator dependence increase the risk of respiratory failure. The presence of a RIJ clot and possible +lupus anticoagulant indicate a coagulopathy, which can lead to bleeding or thrombotic events. HOTN is indicated by the patient's inability to stand and the presence of sensory deficits.

   Assessment and Plan
   62F with admission for pneumonia developing into ARDS. Sputum and BAL
   showing MRSA at this point.
   # Hypoxemic respiratory failure:
   ARDS in the setting of MRSA pneumonia. Possibility of other
   complicating factors; however, ANCA negative, [**Doctor First Name **] positive with titer
   only 1:80, HIV status unknown. Has completed steroid taper. Has had a
   high sedation requirement due to vent dyssynchrony when sedation
   lightened. To address sedation difficulty and attempt to liberate from
   fentanyl and midaz drips we initiated methadone and diazepam IV;
   however, she is still requiring the fentanyl and versed drips though at
   reduced doses. Surveillance sputum culture from [**2191-4-8**] and [**2191-4-10**]
   with rare MRSA growth. Completed course of Vancomycin. IP came to see
   patient [**2191-4-13**] and would like vent setting of PEEP 8 and FiO2 50%
   prior to attempted trach and PEG. Encouraging that drip sedation being
   liberated little by little and FiO2 is down to 55% with PEEP of 5 now.
   Has ongoing diuresis with stable Cr
   - will cont lasix gtt for increased diuresis
   - decreased RR with permissive hypercapnea in attempt to decrease PIP,
   will cont to attempt wean settings
   - Continue fentanyl patch at 200mcg/hr
   - Continue methadone and diazepam (PO route) titrated up as needed to
   allow liberation from fentanyl and midaz drips
   - Cont to follow oxygen sats and conservative ABG to guide ventilator
   settings, nebs PRN
   - esophageal balloon taken out
   - cont slow PEEP taper
   - f/u with IP re:plan for trach and PEG (current plan for Thurs)
   # DVT:
   Found to have L-IJ clot extending into subclavian. The line was removed
   however, the patient
s PTT was elevated initially without systemic
   anticoagulation.  Unclear if this rise in PTT is due only to heparin
   SC, however patient had previously normal PTT on this admission so
   unlikely to have suddenly developed a deficiency in a clotting factor
   unless poor nutritional status is now contributing. Currently unknown
   if PTT represents anticoagulation vs. hypercoaguable state. ACA
   antibodies, IgG positive, IgM negative. Heme consulted and given lupus
   anticoagulant positive and low heparin level, patient is likely not
   anticoagulated and PTT cannot be used to follow heparin. Since pending
   procedure, not starting anticoagulation now, but will need plan for
   anticoagulation after trach and PEG
   - daily coags
   - appreciate Hematology consult re: positive lupus anticoagulant and
   now low heparin level in setting of new DVT. Recs avoid hydralazine,
   cannot use lovenox due to renal function, will need to consider how to
   anticoagulate. Plan for now is to have trach and PEG on thurs so will
   start a heparin drip and follow heparin levels rather than PTT. Heparin
   level can be ordered stat and takes approximately 4 hours to return.
   # [**Last Name (un) **]:
   Thought to originally be attributed to ATN. Resolving with Cr steadily
   downtrending at 2.1 today with continued diuresis. No longer struggling
   with hyperphosphatemia.  High sodium has improved.
   - follow lytes and I/O balance.
   - Discontinued calcium acetate
   - free water flushes at 150cc q4.
   # Constipation:
   - Continue lactulose PO and PR as needed
   - If lactulose fails, could consider PO narcan to relieve constipation
   #Anemia:
   HCT of 22.2 on [**2191-4-9**] after steady downtrend during ICU course.
   Thought to be secondary to phlebotomy. Iron studies performed on
   [**2191-4-9**] and ferritin of 346 along with iron sat of 25% not consistent
   with iron deficiency anemia. Received 2 units pRBC
s with good response
   several days ago and is now essentially stable with HCT of 26.5 this
   AM. Per report, patient has history of pernicious anemia. B12 levels
   are WNL as of [**2191-4-11**].
   - Continue to trend
   - plan transfusion if HgB <7
   # Hypotension/Hypertension:
   Balance has now swung that patient has recently been hypertensive. This
   likely either unmasked essential hypertension vs. incomplete sedation.
   Will allow some permissive hypertension in setting of [**Last Name (un) **] in order to
   allow adequate perfusion of kidneys given unknown relative normal [**Name2 (NI) 1056**]
   pressure exposure for kidneys.
   - Continue to monitor
   - cont diltiazem to 60mg qid
   ICU Care
